name.en: Introduction to Cultural and Media Studies

remark.ch: 英文系其他年級學生請洽教師領密碼卡

goal.en: IMPORTANT: This course was specifically designed for our English first-year students. If you are NOT an English freshman, you will not be able to enroll given the objectives of my course. This theory-based course seeks to provide students with philosophical tools for examining questions, problems, debates and views around the themes of culture and critique and visual culture.

content.en:
ALL COURSE CONTENT WILL BE PROVIDED IN
ENGLISH.
Most weekly sessions comprise (i) a lecturing part; and (ii) a discussion section. Some sessions will be dedicated
to screen podcast episodes, feature ＆ documentary
films.
This three-part course is motivated by the following
questions:
Introduction: What is culture and can we change it for the
better?
Section 1: What is visual culture?
Section 2: What is entailed behind a culture of the
image?

textbook.en: A copy of the course material will be ready on February 20. References include text, visual and audio material. Some required and optional references could be modified in order to comply with course discussions. The following include some of the key course references: Haslanger, Sally, 2017, “Culture and Critique,” Proceeding of the Aristotelian Society Supplementary Volume XCI. Lembke, Anna. (2021). Dopamine Nation. Penguin Random House. Lembke, Anna. On The Neuroscience of Addiction: Our Dopamine Nation (2021). On Rich Roll Podcast. Morris, Errol, 2014, Believing is Seeing: Observations on the Mysteries of Photography. Penguin Books. Rampley, Matthew, 2005, Exploring Visual Culture. Edinburgh University Press. Films: Orlowski, Jeff, The Social Dilemma, 2020, United States. Jenkins, Barry, Moonlight, 2016, United States.

method.ch: 講授 研討 其他

grading.en: ATTENDANCE TO THE FIRST SESSION ON TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20TH IS MANDATORY TO REMAIN ENROLLED IN THIS COURSE. WORK FOR THE COURSE: Weekly Attendance: 20％ [With more than two absences, the student will automatically fail the course. Please, bear this in mind.] Weekly Classroom Participation: 20％ Midterm Collective Presentation: 30％ Final Exam: 30％
